She is married. She is in sales. She does not smoke. She drinks wine a few drinks a month. CURRENT MEDICATIONS: She is on Carafate and Prilosec. layman:
The patient is a 35‑year‑old woman who has had pain in the middle of her upper belly for the past two years. She recently saw Dr. XYZ, who performed an upper‑GI endoscopy (EGD) that came back normal. A sonogram showed she has gallstones. Dr. XYZ’s endoscopy also found a lot of bile in her stomach. She describes the pain as deep and it only happens at night after she lies down. She stops eating after 7 p.m. She tried to change this but the pain continued; she has not had it since last week. She sometimes feels pain and then vomits. She does not have fevers or chills.

Past medical history: knee arthritis, anxiety, depression, high insulin levels, previous gallstone attacks, and PCOS.  
Past surgical history: none.  
Social history: She works in sales, is married, does not smoke, and drinks a few glasses of wine a month.  

Current medications: Carafate and Prilosec. She used to take metformin but stopped because of her abdominal pain.  
Allergies: Penicillin.  

Review of systems: She reports no problems with her heart, lungs, digestive or urinary systems, or nerves. She denies asthma, allergies, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, chronic lung disease, ulcers, headaches, seizures, strokes, thyroid problems, tuberculosis, bleeding or clotting disorders, gallbladder disease, liver disease, kidney disease, cancer, heart disease, or heart attacks.  

Physical exam: She has no fever and her vital signs are stable. Eyes move normally and pupils react to light. Neck is soft. Lungs are clear. She has mild tenderness in the right upper part of her abdomen but no rebound pain. The rest of her abdomen is soft with normal bowel sounds. Her arms and legs show no swelling. Ultrasound confirms gallstones, no inflammation, and a 4 mm common bile duct.  

Impression/plan: I explained the risks and possible complications of a laparoscopic gallbladder removal (bleeding, infection, blood clots, lung problems, bile leaks, need for additional procedures, or further surgery). She understands and we will schedule the surgery soon.
